reviewText:
The moment I fell in love with King Arthur’s Gold is a moment that I have never been able to repeat, and likely never will. My team, red, was at the gates of the blue team’s home base for nearly 20 minutes, stuck in a stalemate that never seemed to go anywhere. The blue team had constructed a massive tower, complete with spikes and platforms for archers that made it impossible to ascend. To make matters worse, it was on the edge of a lake, meaning there was no easy way for us to dig under their tower and attack from behind. I was at a loss as to how we would be able to win, until someone had the bright idea to construct a boat.

It wasn’t just any boat mind you, for it was a war boat designed for ramming enemy fortifications that could also double as a spawn point. I, along with 12 others, hopped on the boat, and sailed towards the enemy stronghold. Arrows bounced off the hull, and someone was in the proper mind to shout “RAMMING SPEED!” through chat as we slammed into the base of the tower. It collapsed with one blow, and it killed around 20 people, defenders and boat people alike, in the ensuing chaos. But it didn’t matter, for within the next minute my team stormed into the enemy’s last stronghold and secured victory.

I encountered several similar moments throughout King Arthur’s Gold, each different from the last. Yet they all had one quality in common: insanely ridiculous action. And that is what this great multiplayer experience is really about.

King Arthur’s Gold is a two-dimensional side scrolling multiplayer game that pits two teams of 16 players against each other across several game modes. While each game mode differs in terms of goals, they all focus around building fortifications in your teams base and assaulting your opponents in return. The three classes that one can choose from and switch between at any point in the game are the knight, who focuses on stabbing and slicing the life and limbs out of his opponents; the archer, who has a wide variety of arrows for any situation alongside a handy-dandy grappling hook for climbing; and the builder, who can harvest resources and build epic structures that will make medieval castle designers blush upon first glance.

Each class works well in most situations. Knights are for when you feel like suicide bombing an enemy’s front gate, or want to not die as often as everyone else. Archers are for when you get tired of dying as a knight and want to rain death on whatever patch of ground takes your fancy. And builders, my personal favorite, are when you want to bugger off and construct elaborate traps and structures that someone will hopefully appreciate one day. It’s a healthy trio that allows for one to never get too bored, as you could just as easily change your style at a moment's notice.

As a general rule in multiplayer games, I tend to like it when there is a certain order to how the game operates. Objective is to kill the enemy team? I’ll grab a rifle, walk forward and start shooting. King Arthur’s Gold is an exception to that, in more ways than one. While a match will always start with some semblance of planning in effect, within five minutes utter chaos will descend upon the map. Suddenly the enemy is digging a tunnel under your capture point, and you forgot to place spikes around the pit of death you just constructed. Your teammates are imitating kamikaze pilots as they march to set off bombs at the enemy gates, and the catapult someone just constructed has just fallen over and killed a builder. And to top it off, you just discovered that not only do sharks exist in the water and that they can eat you, but they can also be ridden like a horse at the rodeo.

The amount of crazy that occurs in any given match never ceases to produce laughter and keep me entertained. Seriously, I discovered shark riding on accident. The simplicity of the game, combined with the number of possibilities that can be exploited, make for one hell of an entertaining ride.

That’s not to say that there are not any problems with King Arthur’s Gold. There is a singleplayer mode included within the game, along with a genuinely helpful tutorial that brings you up to basics quickly. The singleplayer is bland as a whole, lacking any of the chaos that is present throughout the game’s multiplayer portion. The AI is a pain, mostly because the archers have a godlike aim to them and the constant pursuit by them does not help ease the pain in singleplayer. In fact, one could skip out on the singleplayer portion entirely and not miss out on a single important concept that is necessary to know for the multiplayer.

And this may be minor nitpicking, but there are several bugs that are found in multiplayer that I have come across several times. For one, I occasionally was unable to respawn after dying, forcing myself to disconnect and rejoin a server to gain the function back again. And after several matches, I and several others I was playing with had to leave a server because the game was convinced that the new match would not start for half an hour. These were not isolated instances, and whether these glitches will be present for long remains to be seen.

But I digress, for those bugs do not take away from my overall impression of King Arthur’s Gold, which is a great multiplayer game that stands out from the crowd by being something that embraces lunacy and remains grounded with simple mechanics that allow for a variety of strategies.

Highly Recommended!
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
The negative:

The community can be unpleasant, but is generally forgiving and open to new players. There is a pretty steep learning curve, and the lack of a decent tutorial makes this worse. Balance and maps have improved, but I still find long, 3-4 hour stalemates fairly common in large matches.

The positive:

King Arthur's Gold is a truly unique experience. There's something for everyone in this game, whether you enjoy building massive fortresses, killing hordes of enemies, or role playing on a giant map with different races and factions. There is a decent competitive scene if you're into that sort of thing. Matches are usually full of people with mixed experience, so newer and more casual players can enjoy themselves as well. KAG is one of the most unique, addictive, and challenging games  that I have ever played, and is definitely worth checking out.

All things considered, King Arthur's Gold is probably the best ten dollars I've ever spent on Steam.

reviewText:
**The game is dying, It's honestly dying, 67 players online in total and a mere 6 players on TDM.. The devs tried but it was too over- or, should I say underwhelming.**


I played KAG before it was on steam, one of the best games I own (100hrs play-time). It's a medieval, 2D game with sword combat - which is great and requires skill to master - as well as a building game with great physics, animations and gameplay opportunities and many game-modes and mods. The maps are a bit small, but they are big enough for a great amount of PvP combat. Unfortunately the community has shrunk severely down to about 95-100 players across all servers.

I have to say, when this game was popular, it was totally worth the money. Now it depends if you're okay with a dying community in a wonderful game, hopefully some day that PewDiePie guy or someone similar will play it and it'll get more players and a bigger presence on the web.

★★★★★

reviewText: It takes a while to get into, but this is one of the best games I have ever played. You have total freedom to build whatever you want, and there are multiple game modes (Although CTF is by far the best). The community is generally welcoming to new players, so don't be afraid to ask for help. You start with a couple of minutes to build up your castle, and then the game starts and everyone rushes to the center. You could build a tunnel to the other side, or a bridge, or try to rush them head on! Every match is different, and each server has different rules and maps. I had this game before it was on steam, and my hours are in the hundreds. The meta game constantly changes, as does the game. Sadly, the player base is only about 100 now, but there is never a problem finding a match, there are at least two full games running all the time. If you join, you can fix that problem! There is even a roleplay server! If you are on the fence about this, buy it, you won't regret it :D And you will make this awesome community grow!

reviewText:
KAG is essentially a game which lets you creatively ruin dreams

Builders build dream castle

________________________________________________________________

Archers think tree is better then puny castle.

Knights destroy it trying to learn to bomb jump from it.

You destroy it accidentally because you failed to understand gravity.

SuperKnights fall from the sky with lit kegs. (very common occurence)

Some random boat with a bunch of pirates slam into it.

You dislike your dream castle and kill it block by block. (this is when you get kicked from the game)

Someone dislikes your dream and scraps it for parts.
________________________________________________________________

So what's the lesson here? Dont get attached to inanimate objects. Let your inanimate dreams prove them selves in arenas filled with flying men and tree people.

reviewText:
This game can be hard to get into. The small playerbase means skill levels vary wildly from player to player, so in each game there will be seasoned veterans fighting with and against the freshest of newbies. And in such a skill-oriented game, it can be hard to get anything done. So if you're frustrated by stuff like that, you might have some trouble at first.

...But KAG is one of a kind. I've played it for countless hours on both Steam and the standalone client. I could play this game forever. I can't even adequately describe how much and why I love this game. I think the fact that you can look at these reviews and see a bunch of people with hundreds to thousands of hours on a $10 indie game really says something.

It's also got a bunch of cool mods, and people actually do play in the modded servers quite a bit, if that's what you're into :)

reviewText:
A fun, 2D, tactical game, sure to keep you entertained for hours.

GAMEPLAY: Three classes:
- Warrior
- Archer
- Builder

The game, you're not held back with just one class; pick one of the classes that suits your fancy, have some fun with it, and eventually change out.

There are multiple elements in this game that make it worthwhile:
- Gliding with shields (how cool is that?)
- Multiple boats to choose from
- Archers with bombs (deadly)
- Warriors with bombs
- Strategic feel to it
- Build a base using real-time physics (albeit the physics aren't the greatest)
- Customizable appearance (skins, textures, GUI, menus, etc.)
- More than I care to list

The combat is simple; block, click, and repeat. That doesn't mean it get's boring, it gets even better with more playthroughs. (Shields are extremely useful with bombs, duh.)

Workers are able to earn money, and can use some of the stuff to build a proficient base. Trap doors are useful, just put some spikes under, and watch your enemies fall into the pit.

STORY: Since this game IS mainly focused on MULTIPLAYER, it doesn't have much of a story; save the princess. It serves more as a tutorial for a newbie (real useful). The story-mode features multiple levels, and if you don't like the princess, you can just simply  murder her in cold blood, and forget about the main objective.

GRAPHICS: By the screenshots, you weren't expecting something graphically intensive like Battlefield Hardline. Good, we don't need 'expensive graphics', this game's simple textures are simply pleasing to the eye. And if you don't like the current theme, or you simply don't like the color of the workers, you can change it.

You can either search up texture packs, or you can do the following:
- Right click the game
- 'Properties' - 'Local Files' - 'Browse Local Files' - 'Base'
- Find an image editor (Gimp, Photoshop, Pixlr, anything that suits your liking)
- Copy the destination
- Just open the images in the editor :)

MUSIC & SOUNDS: The music is nice, as are the sounds to it. They're basic, but you shouldn't be focusing your main attention on the music anyhow (unless you want some epic battle, boss-scene music).

[9/10]
Everything is nice, everything adds up, the game is good at being itself; a war game. It does everything right, and everything is customizable.

reviewText: I love this game.  That being said, the complete absense of critical thinking drives me insane.  This is pretty much only an online vs game.  You will have teammates that will waste resources on a Taj Mahal pit trap that never sees use or is destroyed by one blast. reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold. Where do we begin?

Let's say you just start in the game. You have no tutorials, you are just thrown into a random game. What do you do? You begin building a fort. You see someone else doing an entirely different thing. Are you doing it wrong? One guy is putting trap blocks over a hole, another is digging a large tunnel with water, another is creating rooms packed with traps and class shops. Who is right and who is wrong?

All of you are right! This game encourages creativity. Using what's around you and turning it against your enemies. A shark in a pit killing soldiers? Turn it into a trap. Enemies built a wall? Launch yourself in a catapult. It is all these different ways to play that make every game so fun.

Assume they are putting heavy siege upon your walls. Off the top of my head, you can:
- Build tunnels for a constant stream of defense.
- Fill a boat with explosives and ram it into them.
- Get a boat full of builders to destroy the small base they built.
- Build walls behind the wall that is under siege
- Dozens of more ways, for you to discover!
To counter these:
- Have builders climb up using ladders to destroy the tunnel.
- Sacrifice yourself by turning the boat back into their wall, toppling it over into their base.
- Knights to stab the builders.
- Put your catapult on a boat for a constant push on each wall.

TL:DR, King Arthurs gold is a fun game that encourages creativity to defeat your enemies.
9/10

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold has something that few other MOBAs of this type can replicate.

Sheer, utter chaos.

The Terraria similarity only goes skin-deep, as the only things this game has that makes it similar to the popular platformer are the ability to build and the art style. The latter keeps things simple, with enough expression in each of the three classes to make them distinguishable, yet not overly complex, whereas the former is a stroke of genius.

At the beginning of each game, you and your team will have a short space of time to construct whatever you deem effective in staving off the enemy. Teamwork is essential, as a good castle is perhaps more important than good combat skill. Once the match starts, sheer hell is unleashed.

The ground between two bases becomes a warzone. Makeshift wooden structures are built only to be destroyed a second later. Knights use their shields as makeshift gliders to parachute into the midst of the war, archers hang from trees and walls, sniping anything wearing a shirt that isn't their colour, and builders hang back in the base, pixelated faces cackling as they toss a boulder into the enemy or pefect a foolproof deathtrap.

The games are fast and furious, but what elevates it even further from other MOBAs is the drop-in / drop-out feature. Is the other builder overruling your suggestions for a space tower and is nicking all your gold? No big D. Just leave that game and enter another. Are you having trouble fighting, or even surviving more than thirty seconds post-spawn? Fine! I'm sure your skills would be valued in a new game. The seemingly obvious issue of everyone leaving as soon as the tide turns is obliterated by the gameplay, however; fortune never rests with one team for long. As such, this game is often my go-to for fast fun before I need to go somewhere and don't have time to be locked into a thirty-minute game, the threat of my status being diminished should I leave constantly hovering behind the 'quit' button.

In conclusion, this game is fun, moddable and a great long or short term solution to the MOBA hankering. In my opinion, it's worth every penny.

reviewText: I describe this game as what Terraria PvP should have been, but it's really a lot more than that. The game manages to keep complexity and high skills caps while remaining mostly balanced. reviewText:
This is my first review of any game so I'm just going to start out with the basics.

Pros:
-Three diverse classes to choose from, each with there own specific roles.
-Fairly easy to build.
-Not much cookie cutting of any blocks.
-Each block can be used for more than just its intended purpose, increasing the possiblities for building.
-Numerous maps
-Archer gets an awesome grappling hook!
-Knight gets to blow people up!
-Builder can drop boulders on face!
-Diverse selection of vehicles

Cons:
-Nothing determines what players you go against (You could end up with team full of people who have played less then 5 hours of the game, Or end up against people who've played over 100 hours)
-Toxic community
-Steep learning curve
-Controls aren't very good(If you spam stab as a knight to much, it will cause him to just keep stabbing over and over and over again till at some point he stops. Or as the builder, you try to destroy some stone on the wall, you end up destroying the ladder your standing on.)
-Not very many game types to choose from(CTF, Take the Halls, Zombies, and Team deathmatch but barely anyone plays anything other than CTF)
-Still a few pretty bad glitches (probably only for mac though)

Summary: This is a really fun game that has a few rough edges, but still great fun with friends and random strangers alike. Unfortunatly, the community is pretty toxic and you will probably be going against pros most of the times (pro knights are such a pain, and are almost completly unstoppable). If you give yourself time to get good and can ingore the toxic players, then you'll really enjoy this selection!

P.S. sorry for my bad grammar and spelling and less then pro game critic skills

reviewText: King Arthur's Gold is a game that looks like a simple side scroller on the surface, but when you get to it for the first time you're throw in to a uncaring world where men, women, and other creatures fight each other in a brutal war over bits of land, and whatever else seems worth taking. Where if you don't keep your wits about you, you may fall in battle at anytime and there're always enemies along the way willing to fight you with such reckless hate that you may wonder why you bought Kag to start with. But take heart there're also those who would defend you, those who would fight for your honour, those that you will forge a friendship with that is so powerful it could only ever be made in the heat of battle.\n\nIn short King Arthur's Gold is an adventure waiting to happen, with many friendships to be made along the way. All you have to do is climb board.

reviewText: I'll start this review by saying: this is the third (or fourth, can't remember) time I've edited this review. Every single time I've given it a thumbs up. The reason I keep coming back to it is because I almost every time I play (coming from a guy who's 700+ hours on this) I find something new I love about it. The gameplay is one of a kind, the skill ceiling is as high as you can imagine, I've been playing for almost 2 years and I'm still getting better, still learning new things. I know some people say this game has a bad community, honestly, I disagree. So many of the people I've talked to and played with in KAG are fun, positive people, while there are, obviously, some instances of less-than-stellar community, they are, in my experience, few and far between. One thing to keep in mind is there is an undeniably steep learning curve. If you're the type of person who can't play a game where you have to get rekt a few times to be any good, this isn't the game for you. However, it's not a punishing game, I had fun playing when I was god-awful, and I have (a bit more) fun now that I'm, at least in my opinion, not bad. I've never gotten tired of KAG. I've played this game for countless hours, yet I can really only claim to be good at one of the three classes, knight; I'm trying to get better at archer and I'm an abysmal builder. While the playerbase is smaller than it used to be, it's far from dead, I still see new players all the time (especially with the sale on) and I often play with people I've enjoyed getting rekt by for 2 years. In conclusion, BUY THIS GAME. Especially with the sale on, this is MORE than worth the money; I can honestly say I would have trouble thinking of a better 10$ I've spent. Buy it, play it, have an amazing time.

reviewText:
This is to Terraria what Ace of Spades is to Minecraft.  It's a team vs team warfare game (played in matches) with some resource-gathering / base-building game mechanics.

I thought this was a good game, though ultimately it wasn't for me.  The gameplay is very engaging and exciting, and the three classes (builder, knight, archer) are distinct enough from each other to invoke good teamwork between players.  I give the game a solid 8 out of 10 for quality.

That being said, the reason I recommend against this game is for two reasons: 1. The community is fairly hostile. This differs for everyone, but some of the core members of the community (those that claim to be anyway) tend to be a little rude towards new people.  2. The developers / administrators of this game condone and moderate global banning - which means that if you were somehow eligible (to them) for a global ban, you would no longer be able to join any participating servers (by default, every server participates).

reviewText: King Arthur's Gold is an intense, 2D indie game that every Terraria and Minecraft player should give a try. It's a compact game in which you have to construct War Machines and Buildings, and use those to wipe out the enemy team, in an awesome 2D randomly generated (If I am not mistaken) world. There is, of course, a tutorial and single player campaign mission(s) which can be played to become familiar with the game mechanics. I have to admit, I thought they were a bit tricky, especially on PVP. This game is a mix of my favorite things, epic, raw medieval battles and of course, bits! Bits everywhere! It's a hidden gem in the Steam Store, which I am glad I've found! I must say I had tons of fun playing it, and I think it's worth your time!\n\nI give this game 9/10

reviewText:
A great game. Side-scrolling PVP at it's best. Create your own fortress then race to tear down the opponents. The game features the ability to construct your own fortress both in a build mode and on the fly. Gather materials from around the map to make your fortress as strong as possible. You can also use those same materials to create devices of destruction to bring down your opponents creations.

Multiple classes to choose from that are all very well balanced. A knight for the up close work, hack your enemies to bits! An archer for the ranged, stick one in their eye! Or an builder for support, build a cage around them! The classes are all very easy to learn and you'll be chopping heads from the start, however the gameplay is not shallow and there is a huge difference between someone who is skilled and those who aren't. As a new player I was amazed when I encountered someone who actually knew how to play the knight well and it gave me a chance to really learn how deep the gameplay was.

This game is a must play for everyone who is is into building sidescrollers(Terraria, Starbound, etc) and loves PVP. For most people who love PVP action in general it's highly recommended! Check it out!

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
1 tablespoon white sugar
1 1/4 cups milk
1 egg
3 tablespoons butter, melted

1. In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot. But really one of the BEST multiplayer experince you will EVER have

reviewText: This game is full of good times and laughs. It takes some time to get used to, but it's a very fun experience when people work together. The only problem with the game is its community, which is extremely toxic to people who are new to the game and makes finding a place on one of the barely populated servers very difficult. The game is plenty fun, and if you do get a good team, you will do well. Though, just like any other team-based game, get a bad team, you will have a bad time. Vote-kicking is a thing, so the players can manage themselves without a mod, though there is support to mods to administrate servers. Though, sometimes these votes can be knee-jerked and people will run you right off the server(though vote-kicks only last 5 minutes).\n\nDespite the griefers, scrubs, elitists, and outright man-babies, it's an extremely fun game for anyone who can stomach the people who play it.

reviewText:
Most entertaining 10 Dollars I've spent in my entire life. No contest, RL or otherwise, I don't care if you've gotten a 10 dollar ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Doesn't even compare.

If you are creative, competative, or nostalgic. KAG will stand out to you.

Slaughter, precision, and design. You'll find all of it here. This game has mechanics that truly keep your mind racing in so many ways, no match, will never play out the same as another.

Living out heroic actions like bomb jumping twice over an enemies citidel, into the heart of their fortress decimating workers and archers alike and shattering an enemies supply of explosives and ammo, at the same time occupying the enemy long enough for your fellow teamates to topple the enemies walls and swarm in for the massacre.

-Absolutly Glorious-

Moments like these play out ever more frequently the more comfortable and knowledgeable you get with the game rewarding skill with beautiful results. But also making so that even the newest player can contribute to the cause.

What I have to stress immensly is because of the 2D theme. YOU SEE EVERYTHING. Chaos and Carnage happening 5 feet from you through stone walls you constructed.

I could go on and on about the reasons that make this game a tiny masterpiece. I wouldn't be shocked if i've played over 1000+ matches in the past 3 years.

So if there is ever a game I will recommend to anyone who enjoys teamwork, strategy, or just being an annoying ♥♥♥ to 16 enemy people.

It's King Arthurs Gold.

reviewText: KAG (King Arthur's Gold) is a entertaining yet extremly competitive game were you battle it out between two teams and one team is left remaining. There are many gamemodes in KAG, including capture the flag (CTF), take the halls (TTH), and team deathmatch (TD). You can even play gamemodes that players made themselves like shiprekt or space KAG. There are even intense tournaments between teams of 10+ players for prize money. After playing this game for quite a while, ive developed my own strategies for each charcater and gained some skill. The price may make you a little skeptical of buying it, but trust me it is completely worth it. Every penny well spent.

reviewText:
KAG is a great game and I have over 136hrs on steam recorded for it and would recommend it to anyone.

However there are a few major things in the game/community that hold the game back:
-Game
-KAG's in-game report system:
KAG's in-game report system is used to gain a vote from people in the game to do things from skipping the map to kicking    a certain player because they are" doing something such as griefing or hacking. This system works on some occasions but widely doesn't. These situations are: Players not voting in votes causing unfair votes
date: Players skipping the map during the game because their team is losing or are about to lose
recommended: Players hurling abuse at a player because of something they built or because they feel like it causing the affected player to give a reaction back only for the player hurling abuse to use the vote system against them gaining votes from friends so the affected player gets kicked
hoursPlayed: Players who did not witness a suspected "griefing
voteText: hacking ect..."player then voting themselves for them to get kicked
helpfulPercent: Players who falsely accuse another player of doing something and rally up support from people who didn't witness the event in chat thus getting the affected player kicked
votesHelpful:
Players who misinterperet someone who is trying to help the team thinking they are griefing thus getting them kicked. I have been falsely accused of doing many things from griefing to hacking in many of the ways spoken about above and many more that I would take years to write. Quite a lot of the above also ties into the bad side of the KAG community

-Community
-The "Bad-side" of the community
If I somehow find I have 5hrs of free time to write the "bad-side" of the KAG community then I would happily rant on and on and on. However my language wouldn't be suitable for steams "Rules and Guidelines" They would make a new filter for customer reviews called: "Help us".

reviewText:
This is one of the most unique and fun games I've ever played.  Ever play SourceForts?  It's kind of like that.

One of the most rewarding feelings EVER comes from successfully toppling down someone's little (or big) fort.  It's like kicking in someone's sandcastle, except they've been killing you over and over as you've been trying to kick it over all game - and then you finally get to that point, maybe you just dug through as a measly peasant, or maybe you plunked down a catapult and started pelting a giant hole into it!

Boy golly, when that thing starts falling to the ground - and all the people inside get crushed and mangled in the process - it never fails to put a huge grin on my  face.

It's also EXTREMELY fun to build traps and see them come to fruition!  Or build a big castle that your enemies can't seem to penetrate!  There IS a learning curve, and the game is very chaotic, but it's FUN AS HELL!

reviewText:
Where do I start?

I have been playing this game before steam for about 2-3 years. Throughout development the devs have been with the community the whole time. They listen to most good ideas and fix annoying bugs within the game.

This was probably the best community i've ever been apart of, starting off as a nomral scrub, and now a tester and a moderator. People are friendly and spread their ideas greatly.

Now, lets get into the game.

The vanilla game is set out of two teams fighting eachother. Blue team on the left, and red on the right.

There are currently three (3) gamemodes. Take The Halls (TTH), Capture The Flag (CTF) and Team Death Match (TDM)

TTH is gamemode where you fight to take eachothers halls. YOu must kill all enemys within the hall to cap it. It takes around 6 seconds to cap. But if enemys are near it takes longer. The team to take all halls wins.

CTF is your basic all-rounder game. Caprute enemy flags and bring it back to yours.

TDM is first team to reach a certain amount of kills. There is no build time in this gamemode.

There is build times in TTH and CTF. Build time is basically time giving your team to build defences.


There are animals, siege weapons, explosives and more!

The game consists of three classes, the Knight, Builder and the Archer.
The knight is the main force of your team, allowing to buy explosives to destroy other teams things, and castles.

The builder is a support class and your main defence. Building massive castles and laddering into enemy lines, he has the main power of destroying blocks.

The archer is another support class, shooting arrows and supporting your teams knights.

This is seriously one of the best games i've ever had in my life. $10.00 was well spent. I may only have 600+ hours, but only on steam. I have spent over 3000+ hours throughout these years.

reviewText:
At first this game looks very promising. It's a pity the only included single player campaign is designed only around the Knight.
Multiplayer will actually play out much like modern FPS games. Yes, there are rocket jumping knights in this game. Here are the unique abilities of each class:

Archer: Grappling Hook, Charge Attack (fires 3 arrows if you keep clicking), Fire 4 arrow types (normal, water, fire, bomb).
Builder: Mine, Build, Deconstruct. Builders make all things including workshops to manufacture items for the other classes.
Knight: Block, Charge Attack (breaks through block, usually killing the other knight if you know how to cheat, and I don't),
Use Bombs (water and explosive), use heavy demolition, fly with shield (further with chicken), bomb jump, weaker deconstruct (knights can chop through wood and dirt, but must bomb through stone). They can also surf over rough terrain using their shield.

As you can imagine most multiplayer sessions devolve into rushing for bombs and demolitions and then most players switch to knights because they are so overpowered. The game could be much better than what it is with a few simple changes to the knight (remove charge attack, have shield only block arrows and melee, make stone blocks tougher, remove supply drops). But as it stands the combat oriented players will win every time over builders and their traps.

It would also be nice if you could make a custom castle or fortress and then use that at the beginning of every game rather than having to rebuild it at the start of each new game. Sadly I cannot recommend the game in its current state, which feels very pre-alpha to me.

Edit: I forgot to add that very occasionally you will hear a strange glitchy (loud) noise and every member of your team will die. There is some cheating in this game. Be warned.

reviewText:
Ladies and Gentlemen, I am the GamingRAM and I would like to talk to you about this little ol' game that I've been playing for a few years now. Since classic mode I have been playing this game, and I have seen the changes that has taken over it... let me just say, these changes only make this game even more awesome. This game is the TF2 of side scrollers, it’s THAT AWESOME!

King Arthur's Gold is an action, building, 2D - Sidescroller, with 3 classes, knights, archers, builders, and catapults, fire, war boats, explosions, explosions, explosions... explosions... explosions.... and chickens and sharks (You can pick up the shark and use it as a weapon in game).While understanding the physics and controls may be a bit awkward at first, once you quickly get to understand it, the game will be either meh, or one of the most fun times you've had. Allow me to describe my very last game that I've played, because there is simply to much I can talk about.


It was a 1 flag vs 1 flag capture the flag match, 14 vs 14. The map was rather large and covered with stone, stone, stone, and more stone. This told us right off that we wouldn't need to worry much about using fire (which is very useful against enemies who build with mainly wooden structures (only usable by archers). The map was more or less W shaped, with a piece of land on each side of the map (for our respective bases) and 1 giant chunk in the middle. We put some basic care over our main base, but decided to put a rather large tower over the edge that connected with the lake, pond, that separated us from the middle island. This proved useful at the time and could not be taken. This gave us the advantage we needed and pressed forth. Sadly we didn't have enough men (many were still building back at home), and we were quickly pushed back. The enemy then took the middle island by blocking all the cave entrances with stone doors (which cannot be broken by knights, only by explosives or other builders). We have kept being assaulted by the enemy until we had built ourselves a catapult to squish them boulders. Then when we ran out of builders, we loaded OURSELVES into the catapult and invaded the central island. We did this, took the central island, was kicked out of the central island, and then invaded the central island again, destroying all the structures they had built on it... and then got kicked out again. To help press the attacks even further, we unleashed a rather deadly combo. We had built a tunnel that lead from our base to the front lines (a teleporting structure, basically), created a spawning structure on the front line, right next to the catapult, so that we would be able to constantly catapult ourselves over to the central island. This finally worked, and we took the central island, for good.

From the central island onto the main enemy base was an absolute slaughter fest. We had tried to climb up onto their overlooking tower (which defended their flag), but was constantly struck down, it was like Bunker Hill. Then we tried to drill our way underneath the castle and catch them from behind, that failed and they filled up the hole. We kept trying to do either one of these tactics over and over again, but reached no anvil. I was beginning to grow impatient and then hatched an idea. I decided that we should built a tower from the very center of the central island, where the enemy could not reach yet. That tower would PIERCE THE HEAVENS, and we would place a catapult on the very top of it, and fly down from it onto them. I had created this tower out of stone (just in case they would attempt to burn it), placed the catapult on the top of the tower, loaded myself and an oversized explosive keg into it, and with the help of a team mate, launched myself directly on top of the enemy tower that defended the flag, blew open an oversized hole, seized the flag, and ran the hell off. THE GAME WAS WON! The whole game lasted roughly 2 hours.

Whats great about this game, is the most amazing things, hilarious and glorious, can and probably will happen every single game you play. I can never get enough of all the crazy nonsense that happens, all the explosions, of all the flying behind enemy lines, and carnage, the destruction... this...

King Arthur's Gold is the game I've always dreamed about as a kid.

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold, or KAG, is a game set in the Dark Ages, with common controls. It currently has three available classes, Knight, Archer, and Builder. The Knight has a sword and shield. You can hold down to have a strong sweep, or click for a simple stab. Holding down the left mouse button long enough will result in a glimmer which signals that you can make two strong sweeps. The Knight can also purchase bombs, which help destroy terrain, and water bombs, which stun enemies. The Archer has a bow and grappling hook. The grappling hook has a range of about 7 blocks, and pulls the player towards the block it has latched onto. The player can also move and climb while latched, and can also fire arrows. The archer has multiple types of arrows, including fire, which can set fire to wooden structures and players, and bomb arrows. The builder has the ability to build traps, obstacles, fortresses, and large-scale weapons such as a catapult.

I personally enjoyed KAG, not to an addictive rate, but I still enjoyed playing the small campaign, creating in the sandbox, and playing multiplayer. There are modded servers for KAG, which I have not currently tried as of yet. I think it was a fairly good game, but would not reach my top 10. I recommend it for my friends with weaker computers, however, because it has fairly good graphics, small world generation, and high FPS. I do recommend this game, but not as much as some others.

~Your friend in the background, Zak

reviewText:
This game has it all:
- Innovative yet simple combat system
- Multiple fun game modes
- Various ways to play
- Multiple classes with their own unique item sets and abilities
- 2d sidescrolling fun
- Platforming
- Crafting/building
- Much More/etc.

I'd reccomend this game for anyone of any age. There's even a setting in game for a kid-friendly gameplay experience. This game is a strategic build 'n' kill that's got a real emphasis for environments and role dependancy. Each team needs atleast 1 of each class to function properly. The environment is harsh with wild buffalo, sharks (SO MANY SHARKS), etc. that can all kill you much easier than you can kill them (which I find hilarious). The controls are simple, responsive and innovative. The graphics are very nostalgic in style but vibrant in colour and shape. This makes the scenery of the environment seem very glossy where it should be, and dingy where it should be. Dark areas are REALLY dark. This game even has a day/night system that does it's thing as you battle it out against your foes/friends.

Overall I'd give the game the following ratings:
4/5
8.5/10
87/100

This game is adorable.

reviewText:
This Review is on the Game known a King Auther’s Gold (also known as KAG).
KAG is a 2D, “tidal styled” multiplayer war game with elements of sandbox added to it, the common mode played in it is Capture the Flag, but there are other modes such as Zombie Survival, and Deathmatch variations, Capture the Flag mode is the most commonly played mode pitting two teams fighting on different sides of the map, with each team given a number of team lives and one base with a flag on a pole. The enemy has to fight to the other’s base and steal their flag or kill the entire enemy to deplete the life counter of their team and finish the rest off. Deathmatch is the classic one life per player, duke it out to the death, PvP. And Zombie Survival mode has a small team of players surviving against zombie AI enemies which get steadily harder each night in the game that passes. The game is Free to Play, but most features are premium based, meaning that, for the most fun, buy it.

There are three different classes in this game, these are, knight, archer and builder. The knight; uses his shield to defend himself, and a sword to slash at others, this class also has thrown bombs. The archer is a ranged class; they can climb trees and fire from a fair distance. The last class, the builder, is where the sandbox elements come to play. To defend their base builders will build traps and defensive structures and also create siege weapons to use against the enemy structures, they also use their hammers and break enemy structures but are super weak offensively. I believe the addition of the builder was due to the popularity of games such as Minecraft and Terraria, and this has not hindered the game in any way, but has made it much more fun and open to other players who enjoy this type of genre. KAG has some decent balancing to the game design. It was mainly developed by a small company called Transhuman Design. The game has some “Mods” released but no full support as of yet. The game has been developed since 2011.

The main graphical design behind the game was based on the small title on the SNES,”King Arthur's World”. This is the reason the game is set in a pixelated 2D setting. I also believe this keeps the game simple in terms of Graphical User Interface. As such the game does age quite well, I’m sure I will be playing it for years still to come, so long as there are online players.

I played this game during the late alpha phase, it was fun and decent, I often enjoyed hours on end slaying the enemy or even participating in “Clan Wars” on the PvP elements in the game. I was in the Best Australian clan, “[AOE]” until a few patches ruined balance and the clan broke apart. And from experience, I can say this game is worth it.

reviewText:
I have wasted so much time on this game, but to me it is all worth it.
It has never lagged that bad, and when it does, it is because there is a riduculous amount of stuff going on on the screen. Perhaps the best part is all of the mods. If the original game ever gets a little stale for you, you can rest assured that there are plenty of mods to keep you entertained, from Shiprekt to Zombies. Let me tell you, if Shiprekt were its own independant game, I would still buy it.
10/10

reviewText:
I got this game from a fairly cheap bundle once, without having heard of it before. The trailer looked so good I just had to get it, and I'm glad I did. I just feel I got it way too cheap, because this is a real gem.

Since the game first appeared, lots of people have asked and discussed how KAG relates and compares to games like MineCraft and Terraria. I haven't actually played either of the two, but I've watched enough trailers and gameplay videos, I think, to say something about the differences. Firstly, KAG is more oriented around hectic team-versus-team combat in a couple of different flavors. Secondly, it features different classes with different abilities that really requires practice to master. The graphics are also 2D, with very crisp, blocky, cheerful sprites. Oh, and there are physics, effects and different player head costmetics. The crafting system is more shallow and simple; you harvest/mine resources or gather coins that you trade in for buildings, other materials, weapons or tools.

The game features several modes. Some of them I've mentioned. There's also a sort of obstacle course mode and a sandbox mode (single player). Sadly, that's all there is of official content (apart from a weird mod example). Previously, the game featured other modes such as a zombie survival mode. The good thing is, the game has a relatively good mod support, which people have taken advantage of to bring the zombie mode, amongst others, back to the game. There are also various other custom modes. Lately, I've mostly played theese mods.

I love the action in this game, and I love building stuff. There's plenty of humor in the crazy battles and accidental deaths (sadly, there used to be more of those, but anyway). Graphics-wise it's top notch. Music is alright, but I wouldn't say no to more variety. There are some annoying quirks to building that I really had hoped they would sometime fix, but they have not. Some latency problems on certain servers (might especially apply to some modded servers). All in all though, it's just a lot of fun.

If the gameplay videos doesn't convince you, trying it should. Of course, it might not be everyone's cup of tea, fair enough. But I, at least, have had heaps of fun with this. It's quite addictive, and even after being away from it a long while, I fell a bit in love with it all over again. Well worth the price.

2015.10.05: The game is still being updated, but not like it used to. Sadly, the people who worked on the game initially have stated they are done" with it. Instead

reviewText:
2013 Game of the Year, hands down.

With apologies to Risk of Rain - it was pretty close.

King Arthur's Gold is just absolutely wonderful. From the lovely chiptune music to the diversity of the classes, to the way the map transforms over time and eventually collapses into the ocean, it's an almost perfect red vs blue game and one of the best retro games I've ever played.

There are only three classes, but what's so nice about them is they vary in playstyle, skill ceiling, and complexity. This is a game good and bad players can enjoy together. It's a game kids and adults can play against each other.

The knight is essentially pick up & play, very easy to learn and difficult to cause problems for teammates while learning. The archer is a bit more advanced but allows for players still getting their bearings (or who just aren't very good) to stay reliably out of harm's way while still contributing to the team objective.

For the advanced player, the builder has a complex range of tools, materials, and duties which are the meat & potatoes of this game, because it's the builder who makes the fortifications and defenses, designs the traps, determines the base layout, and is crucial to the infiltration of the enemy base. There is also resource management to consider here.

All of this stuff can lead to long contests, and in fact the map can become so wrecked that there's a map ruined" option under the vote menu. This slow destruction of the level is more fun than it sounds
date: though. If one side decides to hold out and refuses the reset vote
hoursPlayed: hunts in the collapsing and flooding tunnel systems
voteText: and probably more drowning than you'll encounter in all your other games combined.\n\nThe end result of all this delicious chaos is a rambling
helpfulPercent: relaxing mashup of Fat Princess
votesHelpful: Ace of Spades
votesTotal: Worms
votesFunny: Terraria; and of course the great forgotten SNES classic King Arthur's World
commentsCount: from which KAG took much of its inspiration.\n\nI cannot lavish enough praise on this game. There's even a solid co-op zombie mod if you haven't tired of zombies yet
column16: complete with deep base building and boss portals to destroy. It's a surprisingly slow-paced and often suspenseful take on the genre
column17: the likes of which we haven't seen since Urban Dead. Certainly not for everyone
column18: but worth mention.\n\nThe rest of this game though - that's for everyone. Nobody should be without KAG. It's as good as multiplayer gets."

reviewText:
Quick, fun and chaotic!

KAG is a multiplayer game at heart and offers very little for those that prefer to fly solo, but the fun and competitive multiplayer really takes the cake and rises above most other pixel games!

To start out, KAG has three classes to choose from:
The Knight can really push through a crowd if you've got the proper timing for his attacks. His shield makes whatever side is being blocked all but invincible, as a well timed heavy attack can bash through! You can also glide and surf with his shield like Lost Vikings! I'd say the Knight is the easiest class to pick up for beginers. It's very easy to start slicing through baddies with this guy and get in some one-shot kills.
To a knight in the middle of combat though, the Archer is the preferred class and can snipe long distances, really putting the hurt on the enemy team! Their grappling hook helps them get away in a hurry and they can even fake being dead, so watch out!
The final class doesn't get much attention in a standard deathmatch, but really shines in Capture the Flag!
Bring in the Builder class, the real meat behind KAG! This little dude adds an entirely different play-style to the chaotic Knight and Archer classes, though there's just as much depth to the building aspect as the combat.
His role is much more strategic. The Builder can build walls, lay down structures to improve a classes loadout and even throw together some very impressive spike traps and rake in the kills!
The Builder is a bit less exciting than the other classes and has the highest learning curve. You'll have to gather resources for everything you build by digging up stone and gathering wood from fallen trees, so learning the proper amount needed for a specific structure is key!

If you'd like to see some of the basic game mechanics, check out my First Look (it's a lot older than this review) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QTYlN4485BI&index=7

Overall I'd say KAG is a fantastic game! It's very designed and you can tell a lot of love went into this project. If you're into pixel games and looking for something fast-paced and fun in a chaotic way, this game is perfect for you! And the price can't be beat for the amount of content.

reviewText:
Awesome game that is essentially competitive multiplayer Terraria.

You choose between 3 classes (knight, archer, builder), but builder is the deepest and most fun addition to this kind of game. As a builder, you gather resources Terraria style (chopping trees, mining rocks) and use those resources to build various things ranging from walls and doors to workshops and work benches. The latter can increase the number of things you can build significantly. Building things like drills for faster harvesting, catapults and ballistas for siege weaponry, and powder kegs to wreck enemy defenses (and boy do they).

The tug of war combat is extremely fun, balanced, and fast paced, with matches lasting upwards of half an hour. You win by taking control of all spawning points and then defeating all enemy players. It's not a unique mode, but the gameplay around it is extremely addictive. You want to keep playing more matches because of how different each game feels.

I recommend this to the creative builder type that plays Terraria. Playing this only for the combat can get boring, but focusing on building is extremely fun and makes the work you do feel useful.

reviewText: If you like the freedom of making your own map (alongside with your team; KAG is a team game: no team, no win), if you enjoy a small but vivid community or if you like to destroy whatever your opposer creates; then go ahead, download KAG and play the living ♥♥♥♥ out of it! No match is the same, although the maps aren't randomly generated, the only boundaries of the map layout are your imagination and the effort you put in gathering resources. Be warned: YOU MUST PLAY WITH YOUR TEAM, communication is key in this game, I recommend voicechatting with your friends for maximum enjoyment.\n\nWhat are you waiting for? I'll see you on the magnificent 2D battlefield that is KAG!

reviewText:
From the makers of Soldat.  Great game and great concept.  The game is great as is, but has so much potential, to be even better.

Pros:
-On the fly, tower/castle construction/maintenance, while battle is actively occurring. Placing a great sense of urgency on maintaining your stronghold
-Research and development of weapons
-Option to change classes without the need to wait for death
-Attack from Land, Air, Sea, or underground

Cons:
-Griefers sometimes ruin your experience and there isn't a great way get rid of them. Especially if it is a group of them. Voting to kick a griefer will get you kicked instead.
-Setting up your own server isn't very easy (unlike Soldat).  The process is kind of convoluted. I've tried following guides, but the servers never appear to work properly.  Not sure if the issue is due to the Steam version.
-Current version doesn't have map building/editor. (You must use the Classic version from the website, not available on Steam)
-Some maps appear to be too small
-Resources are some times too sparse.  Making limiting game play on a map


Wants for future patches:  (If I can, I can learn how to properly set up a server/mod server, I will try to implement some of these ideas)
-Tunneling based maps
-Option for team damage (ie. prevent bomb jumping)
-Option for Larger Maps and to be able to building higher. (This may also give more options to use Aerial equipment
-Option for Short keys for changing equipment
-More Building material options
-More classes
-More weapons/equipment options (ie. options to jump higher, besides trampoline/catapult)
-Wish maps had more options to create pits
-It would be cool to see an implementation of molten lava, may be create a volcano/geyser

reviewText:
What can I say? This game is utterly fantastic. Normally when you buy a game for 8 or 9 pounds you expect to get a few hours of decent entertainment before moving on, yet King Arthur's gold has a certain charm which draws you back in like a fish to a worm.
The replayability is amazing, one game you might be a daring knight in shining armor, storming the enemy defences and claiming their flag.
Next you are an archer, high above the battlefield swinging from tree to tree on your trusty grappling hook raining fire and destruction upon those who were born to stay on the ground.
Finanly you a builder, brave yet smart, building tunnels and traps for your team on the front line, or providing shops for the battle-ready knights and archers to use at their disposal.
What i'm trying to say is, this is the best pixelated multiplayer game you will ever play, unless ofc they release King Arthur's gold 2.
The only bad thing about this game is certain members of the community who decide to ruin the day for others, and there are no beginner servers, so learning the ropes is hard, unless you ask for help! :) 10/10

reviewText:
2013 Game of the Year, hands down.

With apologies to Risk of Rain - it was pretty close.

King Arthur's Gold is just absolutely wonderful. From the lovely chiptune music to the diversity of the classes, to the way the map transforms over time and eventually collapses into the ocean, it's an almost perfect red vs blue game and one of the best retro games I've ever played.

There are only three classes, but what's so nice about them is they vary in playstyle, skill ceiling, and complexity. This is a game good and bad players can enjoy together. It's a game kids and adults can play against each other.

The knight is essentially pick up & play, very easy to learn and difficult to cause problems for teammates while learning. The archer is a bit more advanced but allows for players still getting their bearings (or who just aren't very good) to stay reliably out of harm's way while still contributing to the team objective.

For the advanced player, the builder has a complex range of tools, materials, and duties which are the meat & potatoes of this game, because it's the builder who makes the fortifications and defenses, designs the traps, determines the base layout, and is crucial to the infiltration of the enemy base. There is also resource management to consider here.

All of this stuff can lead to long contests, and in fact the map can become so wrecked that there's a map ruined" option under the vote menu. This slow destruction of the level is more fun than it sounds
date: though. If one side decides to hold out and refuses the reset vote
hoursPlayed: hunts in the collapsing and flooding tunnel systems
voteText: and probably more drowning than you'll encounter in all your other games combined.\n\nThe end result of all this delicious chaos is a rambling
helpfulPercent: relaxing mashup of Fat Princess
votesHelpful: Ace of Spades
votesTotal: Worms
votesFunny: Terraria; and of course the great forgotten SNES classic King Arthur's World
commentsCount: from which KAG took much of its inspiration.\n\nI cannot lavish enough praise on this game. There's even a solid co-op zombie mod if you haven't tired of zombies yet
column16: complete with deep base building and boss portals to destroy. It's a surprisingly slow-paced and often suspenseful take on the genre
column17: the likes of which we haven't seen since Urban Dead. Certainly not for everyone
column18: but worth mention.\n\nThe rest of this game though - that's for everyone. Nobody should be without KAG. It's as good as multiplayer gets."

reviewText:
Rating: 9/10
Pro: 2D sandbox where you can play three classes (or more if modded), which allows a varying array of play-styles ranging from the one who builds majestic and physics-induced buildings, a tanky knight that cuts down foes, or an archer that sprays and pays from afar. You can destroy, build, and destroy again with the game, using the neat physics to bring down a tower on your enemies head if you manage to blow the supports. Packed with gore and bits when you are killed gruesomly. Explosions. Blood. Death. More explosions. Why don't you own it yet?
Con: The occasional lag spike that can ping-ban me from servers, may be my own fault, undetermined. Community can be toxic, but for the most part it's full of neat people.
Replayability: 100%. You'll never have a similar round.

Buy it for sure, it's amazing.

reviewText:
This is a good game it has some potential. The fighting mechanics are decent as you can be a knight an unstopable killing force with bombs at your disposal. Or you can be an archer who has a grappling hook that you can use to parkour around and shoot people from trees. You can also crouch as an archer which makes you look like your dead so I have feighed my death many times to get past enemy lines. Lastly you can be a builder to make traps with spikes or make a castle for the rest of your team and then change classes while your traps rack up kills.
In General these are the good things about this game.
Good combat: If you have decent amount of skill you can pretty much be a god with a sword or an Archer who can parkour around.
Fun Buildings: Spikes, tree choppers, catapults, ballistas, those are the buildings in the game that you can use to farm kills and make an impenatrable fortress.
Flaws of this Game
Needs a Larger Community: More players! It is rare to find a game with more than 8 people in it, Even then those eight people will leave and their is no-one to replace them.
Upgrade Mechanic. You have to vote to choose what upgrades to use, and the system is somewhat difficult for a team to decide what to use. This may have been an old bug but You are unable to build the mounted bow turret.
Overall this is a good game with the steam sale and the fighting mechanics you shoud try it.

reviewText:
This is a good game it has some potential. The fighting mechanics are decent as you can be a knight an unstopable killing force with bombs at your disposal. Or you can be an archer who has a grappling hook that you can use to parkour around and shoot people from trees. You can also crouch as an archer which makes you look like your dead so I have feighed my death many times to get past enemy lines. Lastly you can be a builder to make traps with spikes or make a castle for the rest of your team and then change classes while your traps rack up kills.
In General these are the good things about this game.
Good combat: If you have decent amount of skill you can pretty much be a god with a sword or an Archer who can parkour around.
Fun Buildings: Spikes, tree choppers, catapults, ballistas, those are the buildings in the game that you can use to farm kills and make an impenatrable fortress.
Flaws of this Game
Needs a Larger Community: More players! It is rare to find a game with more than 8 people in it, Even then those eight people will leave and their is no-one to replace them.
Upgrade Mechanic. You have to vote to choose what upgrades to use, and the system is somewhat difficult for a team to decide what to use. This may have been an old bug but You are unable to build the mounted bow turret.
Overall this is a good game with the steam sale and the fighting mechanics you shoud try it.

reviewText:
Very fun multiplayer game with many Griefers, little kids, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and (a few) nice players who are desperately trying to have a nice experience.
The game itself (without any mods) is balanced and fun to play but after 6-8 hours of gameplay you probably should search for modded server`s which enhance the game itself with new blocks, weapons, more explosive stuff and new classes.
There are even server´s where you can Roleplay or play Super Smash Bros.
My biggest problem with the game is...THE COMMUNITY:
I know I know there are probably many people in the game who just want to play it and have fun but there are many griefers, random votekickers, little kids, and dumbasses who try to A: Destroy everything which looks kinda big or hard to destroy ( because of the sick physics) B: Argue with you because you are the only one building things for your team and not fighting without equipment C:Votekick without a reason (everyone just votes yes because they don`t care).
Overall King Arthur`s Gold is worth it`s price and I would recommend it to people who like Indie games and don`t care about the bad community of this game!

Without Community: 8/10With Community: 7/10

reviewText:
I always thought side-scrollers sucked until I played this game.

Amazing game that blends the graphics, combat, and building system of Terraria with other elements like cool weapons and vehicles.

During my first 30 minutes I basically know how to play the whole game and enjoyed a long capture the flag battle where my team tried to breach the enemy defenses.

Everybody is doing something whether it's digging a tunnel to go behind enemy lines, building a boat, planting bombs and traps, getting in sword fights, shooting arrows from a tower, or even chopping down trees for wood, there is something for everyone to do without getting bored.

10/10
Highly Recommend

This game used to be one of the best I'd ever played. HOWEVER I will say that some mechanic changes and shifts among the community have caused me to stop playing altogether. Sometimes i will launch this game, muck around for 10 mins then remember why i stopped playing.

9/10

reviewText:
I strongly recommend this, really fun multiplayer game, addicting too. It can be annoying at first but trust me, you'll get used to it. The annoying thing for me at first was to get used to the attacking moves and the buildings confused me. But like I said after a bit you get used and you flow through it all. You can be a knight, archer and a builder & there are also catapults and so on. You'll be switching in between them and since it's team based game the engineers work together more or less when designing the base, defenses and so on. Capture the flag is awesome.

The land gets shaped and destroyed as the match advances. The most annoying part for me actually is the day/night cycle when I play during the day because of all the light in the room, it's hard to see stuff when it's pitch dark in game, but 90% of the servers don't run the day/night cycle and it's only set to day so that's good. So it's a must get on its full price, even better on sale.

A few tips though : You'll be carrying around water greandes and explosive ones. The water ones put out fires and stun the enemy and the explosive ones well they create gore. So you gotta tap F to switch in between the nades depending on each one you wanna throw first when you press space bar. Mentioning this because it can be frustrating to figure it out as a newb.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is still one of my go-to games after a couple of years. The gamplay is fast and strategic, and despite the small roster and resources in the game, there is a lot of depth to be found.

My few gripes with the game come in form of trolls, and how the system/mechanics of the game not being able to deal with them well enough when they do happen, which is not too often. These include people who swap teams just to sabotage, or hackers can glitch through doors, etc. However, when you do have a game full of players interested in playing fairly, it is very satisfying.

I look forward to the developers introducing new classes and blocks some time down the road and how that will change the meta of the game. I have other areas I would like improved, but I'm also an aspiring game designer, so I'll keep those to myself :P

reviewText:
WARNING: DO NOT BUY

The game has been in an alpha state for over 2 years. The developer continues to promise new features but never delivers. At one point they scrapped the entire game, removed all existing features, and started over.

Most of the early players bought the game because it was advertised that a player versus AI coop zombie mode was about to be released. This was over 2 years ago. Now that has been completely dropped, and the game is not any more finished than it was.

Additionally, the game is administrated by a group of young friends who have full control over all servers. I was playing 1 v 1 against a friend of mine on a server he physically owned the second day we got the game. Two game admins joined the server, harrassed us, then banned me from the game for breaking an unlisted gameplay rule. They banned my forum account at the same time so I would be unable to appeal. I was able to use my brother-in-law's account to eventually have the ban removed.

They banned me from the game I had just bought, for breaking an unlisted rule, on a server owned by my friend. The moderator then told us to ♥♥♥♥ off" and used racial slurs. There was a huge public thread on this involving the moderation staff
date: but they deleted it for damage control.\n\nHere is their admin chat log
recommended: search for "yutt" http://logs.kag2d.nl/%23kag/2011-11-25.html\nIt is long and boring
hoursPlayed:
but gives a good deal of insight into the sort of people that will have full control over whether you can play the game. They can permanently ban you from a game you purchased because they don't like your attitude. There is zero oversight from the actual developers.

Imagine if your average TF2 community member or server admin could permanently ban you from the entire game. That is the system King Arthur's Gold uses.


They immediately jumped to defend one of their own
voteText: like any corrupt group with power I suppose. The system was not changed
helpfulPercent:
and the mod was not punished or stripped of his power.


Do not buy this game. Good concept

reviewText: I'm going to be 100% honest: It's a good game, but definately not worth $10. Really, it isn't. The game is only fun of you have a party (8+) of friends, not randoms, to play it with. There is barely any single player content at all, and it's a Team vs. Team type game which is why I said a party of friends, not group of randoms. I'm not into multiplayer games to begin with, and I was hoping it would have at least some single player content, but it doesn't. Just practice levels. The combat is VERY simple, building is as well. That was my biggest turn-off though. It's just hold click, or click. There aren't any different weapons or armor, no skill trees, and very little trading. I'll give the game some more time before I make a final conclusion, but I still will not recommend the game. It just costs too much for a barebones medieval tower defense game that requires 8+ friends in a skype call to enjoy it fully.
voteText: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has great potential, but unfortunately I have to agree with these other reviewers who comment on the community. The game has a very competitive fan base and even on the beginner servers it is difficult for beginners to learn from anyone, we just get stomped. When I have made mistakes playing as any of the three classes my team very often responds harshly. Stomp, laugh, repeat is not an enjoyable cycle. I’m not complaining about difficulty, being a fan of Dark Souls and other challenging games, but it is not fun to be belittled while trying to learn the basics.

I also think the build/destruction mechanic is imbalanced, as anything that can be built can be destroyed much faster and easier. This discourages any good fort building and turns most matches into brawls between knights, with little to no strategy involved.

I wanted to like this game, I even bought it for a friend, but it fails to meet my expectations. I’ll still turn it on to brawl sometimes, but it won’t be the class based strategy kind of fun I expected.

reviewText: The single player isn't worth much...the multiplayer on the otherhand is alot of fun. It is an amazing game and i would love to see this game really big. The community right now just kinda kills it...

reviewText: Fun indie game. You and your team build a castle to defend either flags or halls(basically conquest mode) and then go and attack the enemy castle. You can build catapults, undermine the castle, scale the walls with a grappling hook, or blow the front gate open and storm in. Every match is unique and it's amazing to see what kind of castles and traps people build. There are three classes, builder archer and knight. The builder sucks at fighting and is pretty much only used to dig tunnels, build castles and ships, and in some cases run up and smack the enemy walls with his hammer. The archer has a bow(duh) and a grappling hook that he can use to climb walls/trees. The knight has a shield and a sword and has an interesting sword mechanic. You can charge up attacks or do quick stabs. You can also block with your shield, but you can get stunned by a heavily charged attack. Overall a great game for the price, well worth the money

reviewText:
I read somewhere that this game is like if Terraria and Team Fortress 2 had a baby.

Honestly, that's a reasonable way to put it. It's a game that has definitive objectives and team-based tactics - like TF2 - and has resource mining and block-based building - like Terraria. Of course, the crafting and building is not as deep as Terraria's, nor are there 9 classes like in TF2.

But it has about the same level of fun as those games if you are willing to learn the game and don't get stuck on a side with the occasional griefer. Which is my main gripe: intentional, and even unintentional, griefing is a problem. Powder kegs, used to blow up the enemy base, can blow up your own, even if they were bought and used by your own teammates. And, currently, the vote-kick ability still requires the whole server to cast a majority vote against the offender, which means if the other team isn't feeling very sportsmanlike, they can vote 'no' to the kick.

The learning curve means that some people, usually newer players, may accidentally cause damage or waste resources. It's not a very steep learning curve, but it's enough of one that it's not as easy to pick up and play as TF2.

And there's a few minor problems, notably the fluid-based physics (water spills into empty areas in scientifically impossible ways, expanding into lower regions without actually moving downward, thus multiplying and spreading over more and more tiles as obstructions are removed rather than simply moving to obey gravity).

For the price, definitely worth it.

reviewText: Kag is a rough and tumble 8 bit like dungeon that will test your Lego skills, and twitch reflexes. the games emphasis on castle building, cleaver trap design, and outright destructions often feels like a sado/masochism relationship between players witch will often leave you feeling thrilled as 5 players jump un assumingly into your saw mills, while cunningly foiling someone’s rock fall trap. The game has a lot to work to go yet- a match making system that allows for friends to team up, a feeling of progression or record keeping so you can boost at you kd spread  an there still seems like there are features missing. But with the additions of zombie mode, and rp mode, and a active moding community, this game could go miles further.\n

reviewText:
Why dont they make multipayer modes like this in minecraft and terraria? Seriously this model is flawless. Build a castle and actually defend it from catapults and the other team.

If you like games like terraria but find building things to be a bit of a bore, then buy this game. Everything you build must be practical and structurally sound, and it has to hold up to a keg explosion or 15 or so.

The important part to remember is that it won't. Your buildings will fall and your teams flag will be exposed, and that is when the game gets really interesting, as you desperately build makeshift walls to stave off the enemy advance as you repair your own shattered defenses.

God is this game fun.

reviewText: Gosh this game is fantastic. It's like Team Fortress, Terraria, and Chivalry all perfectly melded together into a hilariously awesome little package. Complete with a realistic physics engine that makes for some lovely siege warfare (Nothing quite like blowing out the base of a tower to have it collapse, even if it costs you a few teammates), KAG is just absolutely fantastic and yet incredibly difficult to describe as well. All I can really say is that it's worth it at full price and a bargain on sale, and that if you enjoy wanton destruction and deep construction, you'll enjoy the absolute hell out of this game.

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold is a fun game. I enjoy the insanity that can go on in a match. The game can turn a reasonably-pretty forest with a lake into nothing but a colossal crater.

Positives
+ The way the game is made allows for good strategic decisions, as well as teamwork.
+ There's something satisfying about running up to a well-defended enemy bunker with a lit powder keg on your back, just charging towards the bunker for a tactical suicide. I was the only one on my team that ever did that, yet most of my team members would buy powder kegs just to give to me to grab it and charge at the next wall.
+ It actually has a pretty good combat system, much to my surprise.

Negatives
- Once you've played one round you've played them all. (The main reason I stopped playing the game was because I played a round that was in a stalemate for 3 hours. It was just such a good round, that when we won, every round I played after that felt inferior and boring in comparison.)
- Playing as a Worker for more than the 60-second setup phase is stressful, and boring compared to playing as the guy that can use his shield as a makeshift glider. (There are on average less workers on a team, so one worker's working is much more influential on the team than a single warrior. I didn't want to be that guy on the team that just gets everyone else killed because he built the bridge poorly.)

All-in-all, fun and strategic game, but it doesn't have too long of a life. I played it for 11 hours, but I'm probably not going to go back to it.
