reviewText:
I've only played an hour or so of it, so my opinion might be outdated. I'll edit or post a thread if a major update/change occurs.

King Arthur's Gold is a game heavily centered and based upon medival warfare, construction, laying siege, and absolute blissful chaos. Oh god, the chaos that you can create in this game... but more on chaos later. Players can choose from three different classes: The knight, archer, or builder.

The heavyset, well-armed knight, armed with a glimmering sword and gleaming shield, clad in polished armor. Those who encounter him flee in terror as he combines his strength and swordplay to mercilessly slaughter his enemies, and his large amount of hitpoints and rugged shield taking blows and blasts away from him, making him an effective tank. The knight can bring chaos to the battlefield with his array of explosives to stun, harm, and destroy enemy fortifications or enemy warriors. He is truly a fearsome sight, and the very core of KAG (King Arthur's Gold). He is mainly an OFFENSIVE CLASS.

The archer is a stealthy assassin, almost the opposite of a knight. He is more frail, but his agility and swift ranged attacks make up for it. He uses his stealth, agility, and ranged weaponry to silently take out targets and provide both defense and offense by firing off a volley of deadly arrows, or by stealthily eliminating players and traversing deeper into enemy territory. He is not a terrible sight, as many players will drop dead, riddled with arrows before they can lay eyes on the archer. Those who encounter them can ensure a swift death if the player is skilled enough. He is mainly a DEFENSIVE CLASS

The builder is a saboteur and master... builder :D, well versed in the art of construction, trap making, and sabotage. WIth his trusty hammer, he can construct wonderous things, from shops to siege engines to ingenious, deadly traps. Players may understimate him and laught at the pickaxe that the builder wields, and will soon have their laughter cut short as their entire castle comes crashing down onto their faces. Their laughter will be cut short once the master saboteur brings a fleet of ballistas, explosive bolts armed and ready, at their front door. The builder is a great support class, and is centered around both DEFENSE AND OFFENSE, with his ability to create great defensive structures and his sabotaging skill. He is a SUPPORT CLASS.

The hammer and pickaxe are not that complex, and so I have decided to leave them out for now. More details are in the KAG wiki as always :)

HIGHLIGHTS: In KAG, you can build a massive castle, drop boulders on peoples faces, effectively destroying them, explode enemies to giblets with bombs, dive bomb people by parachuting and dropping a keg as a knight, hug trees, make friends with sharks, ride bison, recieve a friendly faceful of shrapnel and stone, take a volley of arrows for your team, bomb jump and fly like a pro, cackle as your enemies fall into a millsaw, have your drill stolen and recieve a warm welcome from Death as your enemy shoves 40 tons of writhing steel into your back, load a catapult with basically anything, participate in trench warfare, hug trees and grass, sleep amid nice shubbery as your allies scream in agony and beg for help, and so much more. Lauching your self from a catapult? Yes. Lobbing corpses at people like the Mongols did? Yes. Do an action hero pose and fly across the entire map by bomb jumping? Yes. Rain Death onto peasants? Yes. Be rejected by bison and have a meal with a shark? Yes. Engage in pirate warfare? Yes. Mentally slap yourself as ballista bolts rain upon you because you forgot to cover up your siege engine factory and the enemy bought a ballista and about 20,000 bolts? Yes. Light a keg too early and destroy your entire base, the chat being filled with wow"s and "gg"s? Yes. There is so much to do in this game

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold is a multiplayer 2D sprite medieval combat game, like if Terraria and Chivalry had a baby. If you think you'd really like that, that's cool, but I'm personally not too crazy about it from the time I've spent on it and the observations of my friends who've played it more than I have. Caveat emptor applies pretty damn strongly here: the game is neat in conception, but not so much in execution. Unless you're willing to put up with all of the following, I would not recommend this game.

There are three classes: knights, archers and builders. Archers fire arrows, builders are in charge of managing (destructible) team fortifications and catapults to attack the enemy base with. Knights are the front-line class, and...they're kind of overpowered. I do not say that lightly. It's entirely possible for a skilled knight to continually decimate a good portion of your team. That's not game-sinking by itself, but it's also entirely possible for said skilled knight(s) to bomb-jump right over your castle and start camping your spawn. By the time they finally die, they've probably earned enough gold from killing your team to buy a good number of base-destroying bombs, and his team's builders have had leeway to set up multiple catapults.

KAG's learning curve is fairly steep, even for me, but that wouldn't be as much of an issue if knights were weaker, and more importantly if the game's community was large and vibrant. It's not. It's fairly small and pretty toxic, even for a niche competitive game. This is a problem that Pirates, Vikings & Knights II also suffers from, but at least that game is relatively easier to understand and very engaging at times, not to mention the recent increase in updates to that game has resulted in somewhat of a boost to its player base.

This game is also rather buggy, but I consider that a minor issue compared to the others I've talked about here. Really, it's more of a combination of all these things that prevent KAG from reaching greatness. At any rate, I hope you are now an informed customer and will decide wisely.

reviewText:
I'm so sad. I was so excited to play this game - we went and bought a bunch of copies for my friends and I.

Unfortunately, it's very problematic to actually play. Tons of UI inconveniences - for instance, to load the catapult, you use the E button. But if you just tap E, it removes the wheels from the catapult. Because, yes, totally, I wanted to break my seige weapon instead of loading it. Want to do a challenge? Well, just pick the challenges option, and get thrown into all of them, one after another, with no way to pick the one you want to try. Sandbox mode? Build whatever you want! .... except the map has no water, so none of the boat stuff, and is insanely tiny, so you can't hardly get any resources to build stuff. What's the point of sandbox mode if you've got no resources and no place to put things?

Also, the sandbox mode prepared me for one type of building - and then, in actual multiplayer, the entire process of how you build was completely different. There wasn't any way to practice ahead of time. Again, what's the point of sandbox, then?

There's a lot to love about this game, and I'm definitely going to come back - I'll give it a few months? If they polish it, refine it, and make it the game it deserves to be, I'll be a fan for life.

As is? I'm just disappointed.

reviewText:
So the gameplay is fantastic. It's original, incredibly fun, and it has a small but devouted fanbase.

But this is the most glitch filled mess that has ever existed. Making the game run is comparable to domesticating a shark.

The game ran fine the first day.

On the second day it refused to get past the launcher. Support, while they tried to help, ultimately didn't do anything.

On the third game it ran fine, but I had to restart multiple times to get the game to use my Steam name.

Oh yes, one more thing, I'd say close to half of those three hours I've played are me trying to make the game actually run.

On the fourth day, or perhaps the third day because they are honestly all blending together, the game crashed when joining a game. I updated my drivers today, or yesterday, I don't even know, and the game crashed while loading up the server list.

It also failed to recognize my Steam name again.

I must have reinstalled this game 20 times in the last few days.

This is all such a shame, I really wanted to love and like this game but if I can't even get it to run how could I possibly reccomend it?

reviewText: When I first bought KAG well over a year ago, when the game was still in alpha, I too thought it was an amazing game. However, anyone new to the game will quickly be greated by an utterly atrocious community and even worse developers. This has resulted in, as many of the negative reviews have already stated, two overwhelming problems: griefing and banning.\n\nFor starters, the devs have not implemeted, nor do they appear willing to implement, an in game mechanic which prevents members of one team from joining the enemy team during a game. This creates a situation in which there are no consequences for players who abuse the game by griefing the opposing team. As such, being the lazy developers they are, the devs have turned enforcement of in-game rules over to the community, who in turn solved" this problem by simply banning any behaviour which can in any slight degree be regarded as griefing. The result is one of the worst experiences for a new player that I have ever witnessed. You see
recommended: one is just learning the game and can sometimes make mistakes... big mistakes. This leads to noobs being misconstrued as griefers and subsequently being banned from servers thus adding to the already significant problem of griefing in general.\n\nThis has created an environment in which the community responds very negatively to new players and is often times unwilling to allow

reviewText:
King Arthur has a huge gameplay.
You can see the vids and the store page to be interrested like me.
There are tons of things to do.
But in multiplayer... oh god... this is so frustrating to be overwhelmed like that ! [Long review]


3 classes: Builder, Knight and Archer.
Quite simple to grasp the basics with few tutorials.
You build a castle with tons of elements in few mins (2 or 3) and go fight the enemy and test its own defenses.

So where is the problem ? If this rich gameplay has been implemented it's for a good reason, right ?
It's because there is too much to handle and the game is absolutely unoptimize.

Take a look at the following....


BUILDER:

You try to build simple defenses. Wood, the weaker, Stone, the strongest. The main  problem is directly link to this class: King Arthur's Gold is not a Sandbox game !  As an example you can't move soils such as dirt. There is no editor, so every maps are design by the developpers. An other problem is you have no wooden traps. The only availiable a retractable spike. It can kill your friends and  you have to build a special block that makes enemies fall through instead of you team. The fact is that you have to spend a huge amount of stones to build a simple trap system. Securing a flag or an entrance is horribly long and quite often you get blocked by the trap block" because you can't pass through... Even aiming the blocks to build and even digging is hard. You will rant when you will see this little red arrow with a horrible sound to show "you can't build here" (thanks we haven't noticed !!).
Add to that the fact that when you missed your clic you can't deconstruct your block.
Very nice to endure when you are in the fire of the action and a trap needs to be finished in a hurry ! (in general a guy from the opposite team is coming at you...).

And it's really
recommended: annoying to be rushed all the time by "Airborn" knights carrying bombs (Knight after droping a bomb can use his shield to propels him in the airs and glide anywhere holding the shield above him like a hang-glider). And the situation is absolutely obvious when you see a lone guy exploding the walls you put so long to build.\n\nPeople will tell you
hoursPlayed: you have siege weapons!\nBut you can be propelled with a catapult and again it's a huge boost of mobility. For the non rushing team it's a sentence of death because building siege weapons needs a lot of stone
voteText: A LOT (Wood can respawn but it's not the case for stone). And when you die few times in a desperate attempt to repair or rebuild the structures previously destroyed by few kamikaze... you start to be angry.\n\nConsidering the fact that you just can't store the materials you've found for the rest of the team
helpfulPercent: can't fight correctly as a builder (because you only score points when you kill someone) or even building a decent base at the start (around 3 mins to do it !). You can buy items for the Builder
votesHelpful: such as a drill
votesTotal: but like all aspects of the game
votesFunny:
nothing mentions that the drill overheat and is unavailiable for few mins. So nobody use it. You can understand how frustrating this game can be as a builder.

KNIGHT:

Exhausted of building stuff that won't last more than few mins
commentsCount: you try your luck as a close combat fighter [Not a Kamikaze Knight of course].\nBut it's delightfull to fight and being unable to chain few blows without being overwhelmed by characters and explosions (bobies are persistent and can be picked up
column16: so if someone dies it will block the line of sight of everybody and instead of taking valuables you will take a corpse ...). In general you click in the mass of pixels and hope to reach your target. In the fire of the action you will be unable to see the small hearts of the ennemy (his health of course). Note that if you died you won't have enough money to buy the bombs (you can throw it even before dying to blow everything... Kamikaze Style !).\n\nSo you go to range fight when you have enough of getting killed. If you look deeper on the forums
column17:
you will find that some dudes has mouse mods so they can burst you in melee if you are a regular player like me [translation: a fair play man].


ARCHER:

You have a bow
column19: simple enough ? No.\nConsider the fact that you have a long time to load the arrow
column20: the low damage it does and the fact that you can't see correctly if you damaged the target. You have a special attack wich throws 3 arrows
column21:
but the way to use it is so much complicate that you won't us it. Only in close combat if you have luck to land one or two arrows on the target and in general you have a knight in front of you (whe can use the same shield to glide to protect him... yes sir).

You can use a grappling hook to reach higher locations (by the way it's very hard to build high towers) but this tool is so unaccurate and with a very limited range that quite often you will loose your life in a desperate way to aim/evaluate the distance/ and dodge the incoming foe.
Bomb jump is much better in terms of efficiency and power.
Add to that ammunitions
column22:
because you have basic and special arrows like the fire one to burn wooden structures or the bomb arrow for stone. An other great way to reduce to ashes the work of Builders...

Again if you die you will drop some gold the enemy can use to buy ammunitions

and if you rush and place shops on the way to the enemy base you will win quickly with continuous Kamikaze Knights...


IN GENERAL:

The concept is appealing but frankly the learning curve is horrible and there is too much content.
I never thought i would say something like that...
You rarely understand why something didn't worked especially during a fight where 2 or 3 secs determines the fate of your character.
You have so many game mechanics that you can't handle everything at the same time. As

TO CONCLUDE:

You have better multiplayer games for free with much more balance and interrest.
King Arthur's Gold is not a sandbox and it's a game where gameplay goes too far and makes the multiplayer messy. You can't manage everything and your team doesn't act with you

reviewText: Expected fun and responsive multiplayer combat with a tutorial to multiplayer that covers more than the very basics, was disappointed. Multiplayer is not noob friendly at all and there are griefers. Having to get close against faster moving knights to actually hurt them as ranged character sucks when they can easily block your shot and follow it with a faster strike (because your bow charge is slow and slows you down). The combat doesn't feel responsive at all because of delays - When you are a lone archer/knight fighting against grouped enemy behind doors, there's not much you can do.\n\nThe princess rescue mission and challenges didn't tell how to effectively build traps or various other things. I feel like I could learn the game and it's classes if I kept playing, but having to do so in multiplayer environment with experienced players isn't very nice.

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold is Terraria online deathmatch. The gameplay rollicks on like a Roman civil war stand-off; a grand construction race to build smarter fortifications.

The class system is fairly bland and customization is purely aesthetic. Archer and Knight have uninteresting abilities, and the core mechanics of combat are too generic to make up for the lack of options. It is the Builder class that carries the depth of the game.

It's with the Builder that KAG offers a real opportunity for creative destruction that few other games offer. Unfortunately, that creativity is buried under a mound of busy-work. With the amount of time spent gathering, dying, and watching your buildings be destroyed you'll often find yourself less of a visionary architect, and more of an exasperated maintenance man.

reviewText: This game has a lot of potential but as for now there are too many problems with the game. I believe the game is still in its beta so it's to be expected but there are just far too many problems. For one the classes are all unbalanced, mining and building can be tricky and glitchy at times, the servers are laggy and I often disconnect losing all my items collected during the game. I got this game for around $2.50 so it's not a bad deal. I hope they continue to update this game but as far as I know updates do not happen very often. The production company working on this game also has a few other games, which is most likely why they can not update often.\n\nAll and all I would not reccomend this game unless you find it on sale. Im just going to let this game sit in my library for a bit while the producers work on updates.

reviewText:
King Arthur's Gold is by far probably one of my favorite games of all time, and for good reason. KAG is a tile-based, team-based, competetive multiplayer game that has a variety of things in it that usually contribute to replayability which is a very good thing. There is a high skill cieling which again, is a very good thing but can be unhelpful to new players. To be completely honest this game uses the tile-based mechanic in multiplayer better than moster other games could dream to because of the fact that everything in the game is connected to the tile-based mechanic, unlike other games who make things that would work in a normal multiplayer game but not one with tile-based mechanics. (looking at you Brick-Foce... not that the game has anything else to stand for) If you like slightly team-based games that require skill and have a lot of replayability, then this is the game for you.

Pros:
-Lots of replayability
-High skill ceiling
-Fort building
-Fort collapsing
-Bloody battles
-Variety of items
-Rough resource gathering system
-Multiple classes (different playstyles and helps the teamwork aspect be true to itself)
-Multiple gamemodes
-Seige vehicles
-Water vehicles
-Explosions
-More explosions
-Did I mention explosions?
-Singleplayer for testing stuff
-More players for a indie multiplayer than usual

+/-:
-Teamwork-based (is a pro for me but some people don't like teamwork-based mechanics)
-Light music

Cons:
-Bad tutorial
-More lag problems than most other games
-Some balancing issues
-Some bugs

Final verdict: 8.5/10, if you like multiplayer teamwork-based competetive games that have lots of replayability, (everyone likes replayability) then you should try this game

reviewText:
This game seemed like a great concept to me.
That's why I originally bought it.
I'd been wanting the game for months, and decided to finally purchase it during the Summer Sale.
I launched the game, signed in, and completed the tutorials.
The game's athestics are very nice, and while not ultra-realistic, they are polished.
The game is executed well, too.
IN SINGLEPLAYER.
Build things, fight things, destroy your enemy.
However, when in a Multiplayer enviroment which for me was the highlight of the game, things start to go wrong.
I could not last more than 1 or 2 minutes while playing as the Knight or Archer class.
Any attempts made by me were futile, as the other members of my team refused to provide any sort of help and essentially all tried to do their own thing. This led to me getting killed. A lot.
That's when I turned to the Builder class.
I was great at staying behind our front defenses, and helping to build more defenses aswell.
HOWEVER, if one of your teammates doesn't like the way you set up a fort, or placed traps, they will take it upon themselves to destroy what you built, and place their own structures. If you are new to the game and don't have a lot of experience with setting up traps or building defenses, I suggest you STAY AWAY from Multiplayer for at least 30 minutes of gameplay. Familiarize yourself with how this game works, or you will be called an idiot in Multiplayer.
This was my experience, and I hope you learn not to make the same mistake I did.

reviewText: This game is good and has some awesome ideas going for it, too bad a lot of them fall flat due to balancing issues or the hit or miss community. I love the ideas of building epic structures and working together with your team to take them down with siege weaponry and cunning, unfortunately this is not usually how the matches end up. You'll go into a game hoping to create a grand structure, but you'll be one of two, or maybe the only, builder and it's just not possible to build anything large by yourself, you simply can't gather and hold enough resources to create it before the enemy shows up. And then they do... wave after wave of knights carrying keg bombs, just laying waste to your creations. Who needs a catapult when a cheap as dirt explosive does twice the damage? It's stupid, makes no sense, and ruins most matches. Then there's the lag, I'm not sure if it's happening to anyone else, but i meet the requirements to run the game and it does run very smoothly when I'm playing alone, but then i hit the servers and it all goes to hell. The match will start off fairly smooth, but then it will degrade as the match goes on. By the end I'm moving at slideshow speeds of a frame every couple seconds. MY ping is between 30-100 most days so i really don't know what's going on. I really have to wonder how people with higher pings even manage to stomach it. I tried turning on faster graphics and that literally made things worse, when it is supposed to speed them up. I find it difficult to recommend the game, but i will as if the problems i've described are fixed it will be a great title. Right now as it stands it's either fun as hell or oh-my-god-someone-give-me-a-gun-I'm-going-to-kill-that-son-of-a- kind of experience depending on your luck at the servers. So if we could just raise the cost of keg bombs, decrease their damage, get a bigger player base, and fix the framerates this game would be excellent.

reviewText:
I saw this game popup on Steam and it caught my eye. I watched the video, which seems to be purposely a bit campy, and it sold me. King Arther's Gold is one of the few games on Steam I paid full price for and I was not disappointed. This game has some history and has seen several revisions before it hit Steam. There already seems to be a fairly established online community of gamers so finding a populated server hasn't been an issue for me.

King Arthur's Gold is a 2d online pvp game where two teams build up their base and attempt to destroy the opponent's. The game features four game modes: capture the flag, team deathmatch, take the halls, and challenges. There is also a single player gamemode called Save the Princess" which I have not played as I assumed this game is multiplayer in it's focus. Capture the Flag and Team Deathmatch are fairly common in pvp games so I won't explain them. Take the Halls is essentially point control. Challenges vary map to map but this mode digresses from the other three as Challenge maps often pit players against NPC oppoonents.

Capture the Flag matches tend to last around 30-40 minutes. Take the Hall matches tend to take a lot longer (upwards of 2 hours). I have noticed this game can get a bit unstable after a few hours of gametime and/or with matches with lots of people.

The mayhem advertised in the video is absolutely accurate and I highly recommend playing this game.

Score: 9/10
"

I give this game an 7/10 Pride Rocks as it does have some glitches that could be a problem at times but are fixed with a quick game reset. Anyone with a mind for building in a rush and learning how to work with others without using your microphone would love this game.

reviewText: This game is good and has some awesome ideas going for it, too bad a lot of them fall flat due to balancing issues or the hit or miss community. I love the ideas of building epic structures and working together with your team to take them down with siege weaponry and cunning, unfortunately this is not usually how the matches end up. You'll go into a game hoping to create a grand structure, but you'll be one of two, or maybe the only, builder and it's just not possible to build anything large by yourself, you simply can't gather and hold enough resources to create it before the enemy shows up. And then they do... wave after wave of knights carrying keg bombs, just laying waste to your creations. Who needs a catapult when a cheap as dirt explosive does twice the damage? It's stupid, makes no sense, and ruins most matches. The match will start off fairly smooth, but then it will degrade as the match goes on. By the end I'm moving at slideshow speeds of a frame every couple seconds. Now, let me explain exactly why you'll enjoy this game: It's just plain dumb fun and perfect for close-knit gaming between a group of friends. Don't get me wrong though, hopping in a random server and just playing to your heart's content is just as fun too!

There are several different game modes, all of which are very rewarding and fun to take part in. I can't necessarily choose a favorite. There is CTF, Take The Halls" ( similar to capture-points)

reviewText:
This is a very fun MMO that is pixelated like terraria and it has a server list much like TF2. You can play with your friends in Team Deathmatch, Capture the flag, and take the halls which is an original mode in which you vote on what sciences your team will use and you make workshops that workers from each hall must work to make boats, siege weapons, explosives, and other random stuff like boulders, drills, and mounted bows of death. To win the mode you must take hold of all the halls.
Sometimes you may also find servers that allow you to spawn in ANYTHING!!! Even more rare, you can also find sandbox servers which usually let you spawn in stuff just to keep it fun.
You can try it out for yourself for only $9.99 if you want to find out all the other awesome things about this game!
-The King of Arthur's Gold

reviewText:
WARNING: DO NOT BUY

The game has been in an alpha state for over 2 years. The developer continues to promise new features but never delivers. At one point they scrapped the entire game, removed all existing features, and started over.

Most of the early players bought the game because it was advertised that a player versus AI coop zombie mode was about to be released. This was over 2 years ago. Now that has been completely dropped, and the game is not any more finished than it was.

Additionally, the game is administrated by a group of young friends who have full control over all servers. I was playing 1 v 1 against a friend of mine on a server he physically owned the second day we got the game. Two game admins joined the server,  harrassed us, then banned me from the game for breaking an unlisted gameplay rule. They banned my forum account at the same time so I would be unable to appeal. I was able to use my brother-in-law's account to eventually have the ban removed.

They banned me from the game I had just bought, for breaking an unlisted rule, on a server owned by my friend. The moderator then told us to ♥♥♥♥ off" and used racial slurs. There was a huge public thread on this involving the moderation staff
date: but they deleted it for damage control.\n\nHere is their admin chat log
recommended: search for "yutt" http://logs.kag2d.nl/%23kag/2011-11-25.html\nIt is long and boring
hoursPlayed:
but gives a good deal of insight into the sort of people that will have full control over whether you can play the game. They can permanently ban you from a game you purchased because they don't like your attitude. There is zero oversight from the actual developers.

Imagine if your average TF2 community member or server admin could permanently ban you from the entire game. That is the system King Arthur's Gold uses.


They immediately jumped to defend one of their own
voteText: like any corrupt group with power I suppose. The system was not changed

and the  mod was not punished or stripped of his power.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=9843221

Do not buy this game. Good concept

reviewText:
I bought this game taking in consideration that is marked as a solo game too, but in fact the game is strongly focused to multiplayer. The single players modes works as a tutorial for the multiplayer games.

Some players could have a bad time trying the game since many things are learned by trial and error on multiplayer games. Is hard to enjoy a sandbox" game with this style of gameplay.

I consider is only advisable for people that wants short session of MOBA with some sandbox concepts like terraria. Don't excpect this game to be a sandbox or a simulation game because you will be very dissapointed.

If you are looking for a solo experience

reviewText:
This is a pretty good game. Its core gameplay is pretty good I guess, but the game in general seems a little... Lacking. There are only 3 classes, and that's not that bad. There is also a pitiful amount to do in single player. Let's say that you're power is out. You dont know when it'll be back online. Uh-oh! Let's go onto the laptop and play some King Arthur's Gold. You play for 10 minutes and you finish the campaign. Well that sucks. That's the whole single player experience. Right there. There's local play, which is okay, in itself, but there is also no single-player vs. AI mode, meaning that you HAVE to play online. That sucks because it is the only way to play the dang game. So, the power's back up! Yay! You go online and... Oh. Nobody is ever really playing this. So, the biggest your tiny little TDM match you'll ever get is probably about 3v3. Keep in mind, 6 people. Wheh! 6 people! THAT. IS. SOOOOOOOOOOO MANY PEOPLE. Look past the crappy user count, and then there is a pvp terraria-like game that has 95% less content.

Final score- 4/10: There are many good things about this game- The character skins, the gameplay, the maps, the balanced EVERYTHING *side note: There are NO overpowered items, other than maybe siege weapons, but those are expensive as heck*, the crafting systems, but those are countered in excess by the game's cons.

Notes for Developers:
Great game so far, it has a lot of potential, but really just doesn't make the cut, content-wise.  A few requests: Like I said-    Single-Player vs. AI mode, Steam Workshop mod support, more classes, like maybe a wizard or something, some more blocks, some more map variety, like maybe a dead forest, an overcast field, y'know, for ambience, and, maybe, custom loadouts that might do things like raise an archer's arrow speed, but make them do less damage (These would work pretty well with the afore mentioned workshop support *nudge nudge*),but, that's just about it.

Notes For Everyone:
Wow. That was a LOT of rambling. If this is like your favorite game ever, I'm sorry, I may have exaggerated a bit about the Terraria thing. Really, not that similar the more I think about it. I was refering to the build system and the 2-D retro graphics. Anyway, hope you have a great day and I didn't ruin it :p.

reviewText:
I always imagine this must be how ants engage in combat when they steal human technology. Terraria combined with the combat from castle crashers, in multiplayer with Capture The Flag. Although fights doesn't feel satisfying, the element of building your 2D makeshift castlefort (for the team?) brings a grin to my face for every spike-impaled kill I earn. Friend or foe, if you falling through that trap door that took me 5 minutes of clicking on a potato-video sized pixel to gather and build, I earned the right to make you respawn again.

There are 3 classes you can switch to, in base and with no appended respawn time. Archers, for artillery support, knights for frontline infantry, and builders for defense and utilities.

Knight combat on its own, without limited items like bombs to aid you, feels like a samurai duel, where if you swing first you better do more consecutive damage on the follow up, to kill him before he kills you.

Archers feels like Benjamin franklin kiting away from the inevitable lightning from Zeus, however if you sneeze at the right time, you might hurt the sky, I just shoot up and hope it lands on someone, cause knights just raise their shields and I can't really do much on this guy.

Bob the builder (my favorite class), has the power to build a series of workshops that introduces the little tribal village of your team to mercantilism. Think of it as a tech tree class for your civilization, except you, the urban planner won't get paid for the layouts, nor the progression of your tribe's conquest. You are a humble servant that fills his needs by serving the land for your team. Scavenging the rocks from the ground, and the berries in the trees, wishfully thinking maybe one day your team might meander far enough to bring home the flag of the enemy.

This is medieval soldat, but a balanced complete 2D destructibility, where players actively repairs and grow the base, this is a game for you. For 3 bucks it's a steal.

reviewText: If you ask me,this game is a pretty good game. There are 4 gamemodes which are all fun that you can enjoy,this also improves replayibility since if you are bored of a gamemode you can switch to the other. The game has 3 classes.Builder: Who is there to mine the stone and the gold,chop down the forest and build a castle,protect the place,set up traps,There is a knight who is there for the fight and there is an archer who usually supports the knights with his arrows and helps the team. You can buy explosives (Capture the flag) or do research,and make factories and wait for them to make your own stuff (Take the Halls) There are only 2 classes (Archer and Knight) in 2 gamemodes (Challenge and Team Deathmatch) since it wouldnt make sense to build in Challenges( Parkours etc) and Team Deathmatch. However Take The Halls is some kinda Team Deathmatch with builders and places to capture. While in Capture The Flag you have to defend your own base and its flags and bring the other teams flags and there are no factories and you buy stuff unlike Take The Halls. There are Siege Units and lots of other things you can enjoy. Gotta love the job. 9/10 if you ask me.

reviewText: King Arthur's Gold is quite a good game. It takes the building mechanics of Terraria, mashes it in with blood lust and vehicles, and then adds just a touch of- oh no- that is way more than a touch! IT IS FREAKING CHAOTIC AND INSANE AND FUN!  I can't explain it completely, but no match is the same. There are three stages to every match. The building stage, marked by a grace period to build and stuff, the... in-between phase, marked by people dashing around just trying to make enough cash to buy a massive bomb, and the final phase, marked by someone actually managing to coordinate an attack, which ends up decimating the other team and making an insane war-zone of death and chaos.\n\nThe only con I can think of is the very chaos that makes it so original. When you start playing, it is incredibly confusing, and you end up failing a lot. Because of this, this game isn't for everyone, but if you can push past that bit, King Arthur's Gold is truly a gem.

reviewText:
The premise behind King Arthur's Gold is a good one. A mixture of sandbox, player versus player action, set in a 16-bit medieval pixel world. The result could have been better, but it could also have turned out to be much worse.

First off, even though this game has been out for at least two years at the time of this writing, the developers have always been extremely active in patching and updating their creation. With that said, their software is prone to crashing often at the end of matches for whatever reason. Besides that, the game performs well enough. The pixel art is cute and fun to look at, while the sound design also provides a nice experience. All the maps available are by design, and the only variety will come from the role of builders, as they will carve through and add to the already existing landscapes. The team deathmatch mode is the least exciting game type I tried, and I've never gone into a sandbox only server. The most fun I had was playing Capture the Flag mode.

The main problem with King Arthur's Gold comes from its small player-base. Finding a server to play on has not been a problem in my region, but there are usually no more than four. Most of the player-base seems to be from Europe. Playing matches in a more distant server is doable, but of course, there will be much lag, which will hinder your gameplay experience significantly. The other problem that comes with the small player-base is that most people playing are King Arthur's Gold veterans, likely with 50 or 100 hours or more of experience with the game. This means that for newcomers, being killed quickly and easily will occur quite often. Someone just starting out is no match for the majority of the opposing team. This uneven playing field does not make for a very enjoyable experience. With that said, there are some helpful and friendly players to be found. I asked some questions a few times and at least one person answered me without making a rude or useless remark. In addition, I've noticed that many of the players know each other, and are familiar with one another, as they often post greetings as soon as joining the server. This made for a warm and welcoming environment to be a part of. Being that King Arthur's Gold is a multi-player online game, you should also expect some annoyances to come from immature and rude players in the chat, but it really does not happen that often, from what I've experienced in about twelve and a half hours of playing. If there were more players, and If there was a more even environment in relation to player skill, King Arthur's Gold would be a much more enjoyable experience. It's a shame that a game with so much potential has such a small, but dedicated player-base. It's probably too late for a revival.

King Arthur's Gold is okay.

reviewText:
First of all, there are 3 classes- the Knight is the only one that matters in this game. Archers exist to assist Knights, Builders exist to stop knights. This entire game is about knights.

There are ALOT of bugs in this game, if you hit an arrow sticking out of a block, or the perfect corner of a block, or some random other stops your chara stops moving and you have to jump and keep going- VERY frustrating when it keeps happening and it costs you a flag in CTF.

Stuns- I have no idea what stuns a knight, there seems to be no rhyme or reason. He jabs your shield he's not stunned, you jab his you get stunned. Randomly they interupt your slash but you cannot interupt theirs. Shield bashing (landing on their head with your shield) stuns... randomly.

Stomping- There seems to be no minimum height to one shot someone by jumping on their heads, some knight jumped over two blocks and landed on my head and stomped me" ... no idea what this mechanic was intended to do.

Slashing- I slash a knight
date: he walks right through it 0 damage. He slashes from 8-9 blocks away and teleports through me one shotting me. I understand this is lag however it brings me to the BIGGEST problem with this game.\n\nLAG- 33 ping is 0 ping for TF2 quality games
recommended: 133 ping appears to react like 600 ping in TF2 quality games. The lag in this game appears to only show 33
votesHelpful: and 400. No idea what my ping is. Join a game that says "33 ping to server!" Get in game it's 133+. This game is poorly
votesTotal: if at all
votesFunny: optimized for lag.\n\nThe DEVs- Are clueless
commentsCount: while all these bugs are still in their game they're making some B.S. top down worthless mod. Game hasn't been updated supstantially since it went GOLD."

It was good while it lasted but the story was incredibly short and boss battle was incredibly annoying and hard

reviewText: I personally don't recommend this game. First of all, King Arthur's Gold dosen't even have actual fullscreen. It gets on my nerves when games with great potential dosen't include a full screen that covers your entire screen. Secondly, it requires a login. I don't understand why some Steam games do this. It really does ruin the fun. Finally, the multiplayer is a bit buggy. My friends and I had some troubles joining each other. I really hope the developers improve upon this game. It really has some great potential.
